verses.text: 勸以色列歸向 神以色列啊，回轉吧！回到耶和華你的 神那裡，因為你是因自己的罪孽跌倒的。

words.note: Often used in religious context of turning to God.
Capitalized to denote the one God.
Often implies spiritual repentance.
The personal name of God in the Old Testament.
Capitalized to denote the one God.
Refers to deep-seated sin or evil deeds.
Can imply spiritual failure or moral lapse in biblical context.
Refers to the authoritative Hebrew text of the Jewish Bible.

verses.text: 你們預備好要說的話，歸向耶和華，對他說：「除去我們一切罪孽，悅納我們的禱告。這樣我們就把嘴唇的果子獻上。

words.note: Often used in religious context of turning to God.
The personal name of God in the Old Testament.
Refers to deep-seated sin or evil deeds.
Often used for God's favorable acceptance of offerings or prayers.
Can also be a verb 'to pray'.
Often used for presenting offerings to God.

verses.text: 亞述不能救我們，我們必不再騎埃及的馬；我們親手所做的，我們必不再稱為『我們的 神』；因為在你那裡，孤兒才得著憐憫。」

words.note: Nominalizes the following verb phrase.
Capitalized to denote the one God.
Often refers to God's compassionate mercy.

verses.text: 神再施憐愛「我必醫治他們背道的病，甘心樂意愛他們，因為我的怒氣已經遠離他們了。

words.note: Capitalized to denote the one God.
Refers to compassionate love.
Refers to turning away from the right path or faith.
An idiom meaning 'with a willing and joyful heart'.
Indicates completion or change of state.

verses.text: 我對以色列要像甘露，他必像百合花開放；他要扎根，如黎巴嫩的香柏樹。

words.note: Figuratively, refreshing and life-giving.
A common beautiful flower, often used symbolically.
Figuratively, to become established or firm.
Cedars of Lebanon are known for their strength and longevity.

verses.text: 他的幼枝必伸展，他的榮美要像橄欖樹，他的香氣必如黎巴嫩的香柏樹。

words.note: Often used in poetic or botanical contexts.
Indicates certainty or strong imperative.
More formal/poetic than just 'beauty'.
Olive trees are symbolic in the Bible.
Indicates certainty or strong imperative.
Cedars of Lebanon were famous for their grandeur and strength.

verses.text: 他們必再住在他的蔭下，使五穀生長。他們必發旺像葡萄樹，他們的名聲要像黎巴嫩的酒。

words.note: Indicates certainty or strong imperative.
Poetic or formal usage for 'in the shade'.
Refers to various staple grains.
Indicates certainty or strong imperative.
Often used in contexts of growth and prosperity, especially in a biblical sense.

verses.text: 以法蓮與偶像還有甚麼關係呢？答允他的是我，看顧他的也是我。我像一棵青翠的松樹，你的果子是從我而得。」

words.note: Refers to the tribe or territory of Ephraim.
More formal than 'dāyìng' (答應).
Turns the preceding phrase into a noun.
Often used for divine care or pastoral oversight.
Turns the preceding phrase into a noun.
Often used in poetic descriptions of nature.
Literary connective, here implies 'and thus'.

verses.text: 誰是智慧人，讓他明白這些事吧！誰是有見識的人，讓他領會這一切吧！因為耶和華的道路是正直的，義人要行在其中，惡人卻必在其上絆倒。

words.note: Refers to someone possessing wisdom, especially spiritual insight.
Softens a suggestion or command.
Softens a suggestion or command.
The personal name of God in the Old Testament.
Often used metaphorically for God's ways or teachings.
Often means 'to conduct oneself' in ethical contexts.
Classical pronoun, here refers to 'the way'.
Indicates certainty or strong imperative.
Classical pronoun, here refers to 'the way'.
Can be literal or metaphorical (e.g., stumble spiritually).
